H0.text: Scales are what a reptile’s skin is covered in to protect it from drying out.

H1.text: Bacteria cover a reptile’s skin to protect it from drying out.

H2.text: Oil is a substance that covers reptiles’ skin to protect them from drying out.

H3.text: Dye is what reptiles' skin is covered in to protect them from drying out.

A4.text: Its scales are made of keratin and are used for protection, similar to an armadillo's armor.

A5.text: The scales of all reptiles have an epidermal component (what one sees on the surface), but many reptiles, such as crocodilians and turtles, have osteoderms underlying the epidermal scale.

A6.text: Cells in the epidermis contain a structural matrix of keratin, which makes this outermost layer of the skin almost waterproof

A7.text: Cornification is the process of forming an epidermal barrier in stratified squamous epithelial tissue
